section.title: Determinants: First Examples and cofactor expansions

subsection.title: Motivation and first examples
subsection.p: We begin by recalling three primary goals of this course:

ol.li: Solving systems of linear equations, a.k.a. solving the matrix equation Ax=b (we've studied this problem in detail).
Solving the matrix equation Ax=\lambda x, where \lambda is a number (the eigenvalue problem). We are currently studying this problem.
"Almost solving" the matrix equation Ax=b (we will study this problem).

subsection.p: As we have seen that solving matrix equations Ax=b are much easier if we can find an inverse matrix A^{-1}, it is natural to ask for a numerical procedure to quickly test invertibility of matrices. It turns out that there is a very nice answer to this question, which is provided by the theory of determinants.

Given any square \ n\times n matrix A (there is no such thing as a determinant for a non-square matrix!), the determinant of A is a number, called \det A. We will see several ways to describe this number.

In fact, determinants are actually an instance of something you already know about: volume. Specifically, the n many columns of a square n\times n matrix A are all n-dimensional vectors. These n vectors determine a parallelepiped in \R^n, which we will call the parallelepiped for A. For example, if A is a 2\times2 matrix whose columns are non-zero vectors v and w, that is, if A=\spalignmat{v; w}, then we have the parallelogram determined by v and w:

figure.caption: The parallelgram determined by two vectors v_1 and v_2 in \R^2

subsection.p: Similarly, if A is a 3\times3 matrix, then we obtain three vectors in \R^3, which define a parallelepiped:

figure.caption: The parallelepiped determined by three vectors in \R^3

paragraphs.title: Key Observation
paragraphs.p: The matrix A is invertible if and only if the parallelepiped for A has non-zero volume, i.e., if and only if the parallelepiped is not "flat".

subsection.p: This is not too hard to believe, especially in low-dimensional cases. For example, if A is a 2\times2 matrix whose columns are non-zero vectors v and w, then we know that the matrix is invertible exactly when v and w are linearly independent, which happens exactly when they don't lie on the same line (neither is a scalar multiple of the other). But this occurs exactly when the parallelogram for A in isn't "squashed."
We shall later see that the determinant of A is a number associated to A whose absolute value is the volume of the parallelepiped for A.

Before jumping into general formulas for and the definition of the determinant, we consider a few examples. If n=1, then we know that a real number a is invertible (i.e., 1/a makes sense) exactly when a\neq0. It is thus reasonable to define the determinant of the matrix \spalignmat{a} to simply be a itself. That is, for any real number a, we have \det\mat{a}=a. In this case, we can also think of 1-dimensional "volume" as length, and the "parallelepiped for A" is just the vector a in \R^1.

In the case of a 2\times2 matrix A=\mat{a b; c d}, the explicit formula is \det A =ad-bc. It may seem that this formula has little to do with volume. However, it is a fun geometry problem to show that the parallelogram for A in has area |ad-bc| (first think about the case when the first column of A lies on the x-axis). As another fun problem, one can perform row reduction directly on A to find that the reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix I_2 exactly when ad-bc\neq0 (although we omit the calculation here).

Then, we multiply all the entries on each slash together, and add the products of the downward ones, and subtract the products of the upwards ones. For example, to find the determinant of A=\mat{1 3 5; 2 0 -1; 4 -3 1}, we draw the picture

Beoynd n=3, the formula for the determinant gets more complicated. In the subsequent sections, we will give several different ways for computing the determinant, we will apply them to give a general formula for the inverse of a matrix, and we will see how they can be thought of as stretch factors for linear transformations. That’s a lot to do, so let’s get going!

subsection.title: DCofactor expansions
subsection.p: We begin by describing one formula for determinants. This definition may seem strange, and we will have to wait to see where it comes from and how it is connected to invertibility and volumes. However, it is convenient for calculations and will be enough to kick off our study of the determinant.

We will build up this cofactor expansion from the ground up in a recursive procedure. Namely, this method will say how to compute the determinant for n\times n matrices, assuming we already know how to do so for (n-1)\times(n-1) matrices.

Let's start at the beginning. First, we require determinants for 1\times1 matrices. As discussed in the last section, the natural definition of the determinant in this case, which is correct one, is \det\mat a=a. To give our general formula, we first need to introduce a little notation.

statement.p: Suppose that A is an n\times n matrix A.
The (i,j)-th minor, denoted A_{ij}, is the (n-1)\times (n-1) matrix obtained from A by deleting the i-th row and the j-th column.
The (i,j)-th cofactor \ C_{ij} is defined in terms of the minor by C_{ij}=(-1)^{i+j}\det A_{ij}.

subsection.p: Using , we can describe our procedure for computing determinants as follows.

algorithm.title: Cofactor/Laplace expansion
algorithm.p:
To compute the determinant of a square matrix, do the following.
Choose any row or column of A.
For each element a_{ij} of this row or column, compute the associated cofactor C_{ij}.
Multiply each cofactor by the associated matrix entry a_{ij}.
Result: The sum of these products is \det A.

subsection.p: In formulas, this says that if we pick row i to "expand along," then the cofactor expansion formula is \det A=\sum_{j=1}^n a_{ij}C_{ij}, where in the sum the number i is fixed. Similarly, if we pick column j to expand along, then we obtain a formula \det A=\sum_{i=1}^n a_{ij}C_{ij}. Note that this gives 2n seemingly-different formulas, which all give the same number! We will see why this is true later, and simply assume this for now.
Let's try this out for a general 2\times2 matrix A=\mat{a b;c d}. The minors are computed as follows:
In the next example, we use cofactor expansion to re-derive the formula for the determinant of a 3\times 3 matrix.
Here we perform the computation for a particular matrix.

statement.p: We find the determinant of A= \mat{2 1 3;-1 2 1;-2 2 3}. We make the somewhat arbitrary choice to expand along the first row. We compute the minors as A_{11} = \mat{2 1;2 3} \quad\quad A_{12}=\mat{-1 1;2 3} \quad\quad A_{13}=\mat{-1 2;-2 2}. Computing these 2\times 2 determinants, we have \det A_{11}=4,\quad\quad \det A_{12}=-1,\quad\quad \det A_{13}=2. By inserting signs, we find that the cofactors are C_{11}=\det A_{11}=4,\quad\quad C_{12}=-\det A_{12}=1,\quad\quad C_{13}=\det A_{13}=2. Thus, \det A=a_{11}C_{11}+a_{12}C_{12}+a_{13}C_{13} =2(4)+(1)+3(2)=15.

subsection.p: With this method, much larger determinants are also easy to compute, especially when there are lots of zeros in a row or column. Generally speaking, it is a good idea when computing an example to try to expand along a row or column with as many zeros as possible, or at least with the smallest entries possible.

Although this technique works reasonably quickly in most small examples, several important questions remain:
Where do these formulas come from?
How do we know that these numbers give the same answer regardless of which row or column we choose (that is, this method gives 2n different expressions for the same number attached to an n\times n matrix, which we claim are always all equal).
Why does this number have to do with invertibility?
